body: This is likely due to an linker error. Try to change the BLAS options in config.mk to atlas, or blas to see what works for you

mean.bin will be generated automatically if the path doesn't exits. Please refer the document https://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/python/io.html for more detail
@hetong007 Let us know if you could help. Since you setup the travis for xgboost

my suggestion is USE_BLAS=AUTO in default

if osx, then set it to apple, otherwise probably just blas, or auto check what is available.
@tqchen Do I need to change the variable USE_BLAS to the path of my atblas or do I have to add a new variable USE_BLAS_PATH to my atblas path?
I think only changing USE_BLAS should be fine. As lonng as the atlas is in LD_LIBRARY_PATH

This could due to the memory allocation policy used for the distributed KVStore under mode kvstore_type =  'device'.  I guess this should not be the case for kvstore_type=local 

When we do device type kvstore, what is needed is we allocate the reduction temporal memory on each of the device. We do it in a random assignment way.here https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/kvstore/kvstore_device.h#L36 to balance the temp weight memory on each device.

If the weight is not uniformly distributed (e.g there is a weight that is particularly big chunk of weight), then this could cause the imbalance.
是的，我是使用kvstore=device，可不可以添加一个比较确定的分配策略？例如从weight从大到小贪心，总是放到当前weight最少的设备，我觉得不少人会喜欢把显存用得满满的，如果随机的话，就有偶尔爆显存的顾虑，即使是随机在显存分配上最好也有个默认的seed，这样不用担心显存每次跑起来不一样：）

This seems to be a good idea. The allocation strategy code is here https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/kvstore/kvstore_device.h#L36

Maybe you can consider hack it a bit and contribute back :) ?
yes，I will

I changed the config.mk file like this:

```
# choose the version of blas you want to use
# can be: mkl, blas, atlas, openblas
USE_STATIC_MKL = NONE
USE_BLAS = atlas
```

Then set the LD_LIBRARY_PATH to  `/usr/lib4/atlas`
But when I rebuild mxnet, I got this error:

```
/usr/bin/ld: cannot find -lcblas
collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status
make: *** [lib/libmxnet.so] Error 1
```
You might also want to set LIBRARY_PATH as well. LD_LIBRARY_PATH is used for runtime search of libraries, LIBRARY_PATH is used for compile time search

I now started to think that we should do such change on R's side as rewrap the mx.nd.array is fairly easy from R's side. Let us move `mx.nd.array` to `mx.nd.internal.array` and create the wrapper as tong suggested.

@hetong007 Can you do that? You only need to change https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/R-package/src/ndarray.cc#L387 On cpp side to mx.nd.internal.array
I think so. I think I will modify things tmr, e.g. travis ci, this wrapper and the symbolic ones.
Great. thanks tong

Tried this too, no luck:

```
export LIBRARY_PATH=/usr/lib64/atlas
```

I also tried openblas, which I installed at /usr/local/lib and /usr/local/include, this time the make command doesn't give me any error, but when running the mnist example, I still get this error:

```
OSError: /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/mxnet-0.5.0-py2.7.egg/mxnet/libmxnet.so: undefined symbol: cblas_sgemm
```

好的，我知道改Init是最优雅的实现，不过要改一下Init的接口，把contexts传进来

Let me see, do you really need context? 

Since the update function is in a first come first allocate strategy. You can compute the information you need (Size of the variables in Init), and do allocation in Merge

another possible way is, do random assignment if the size < bigarray_bound_, otherwise, evenly split the array into num_dev parts, and assign one part to each device

This dep checking of slice might block other slices, as we do not
distinguish between non overlapping slices. So the current way is easier

Please make sure you `make clean` before you make. Also watch for the compile logs. see if -DMSHADOW_USE_CUDA=1 is printed during the compilation. Re-install with the setup.py

I have did my best to make the mxnet compatible with original VS2013, but I failed. Too many unsupported features I came across. VS2015 may provide a better support, but it can't work together with CUDA.

As far as I know, the only solution is to patch the VS2013 using Nov 2013 CTP and let CUDA mistake it as official VS2013 compiler.

comment: 
1. Could you remove Baidu Yun stuff? It is bad to point to 3rd binary(such as XcodeGhost)
2, Maybe we can consider to use VS Community instead of 2013

@happynear  I think we should host thirdparty libraries. But let us fully consider the license issues. It would be really nice if we can enable user to compile these(or give user instruction to doing so) as well. 

On hosting the compiled binaries, maybe we can consider using github's release service, which allows attachment of binaries files.

In my understanding I think we should left all in dynamic way (front end) if it doesn't hurt performance. I plan to move optimizer back because there is a problem of unstable speed. I am not sure whether is the optimizer made it. If so, definitely we should move it back

> a problem of unstable speed

Do you mean something like #223 ?
Yes, my guess is optimizer brings too much load to engine, but need experiment to support the guess. will do it maybe in next week.

Most of the design reflects [Amdahl'law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amdahl%27s_law). In summary, we should being able to support a "mixed way" and allow seamless shift between the two.

The optimizer problem @antinucleon mentioned is kinda like "solved" in a sense that we make the multi-gpu speed roughly linear. There are multiple reasons for slow down, while the stabilized speed is still quite reasonable.

As we advocate for being "mixed", the current design enables both, and we should keep doing so. I think idea of putting optimizer on front-end is valuable, and it won't change even we allow expose c++ level optimizer (allow user to switch between the two).

For operators, It is definitely important to support customization, whether it is native Julia, or via composition of fine-grained symbols and ndarray, to enable user to do things efficiently. 

As some common pattern occur, it may be reasonable to bring some of new big operators to backend. I guess slight divergence won't be a big problem, as long as we have a fixed set of common modules, and interchangeable format.
@happynear Please let us know when you have any updates
@junranhe Let us now if you have any updates. Hopefully we can do it by only changing implement the function Init and Merge

+1 for "official" instructions that avoid any possible licensing and other potential issues, especially since recent news about lots of Chinese developers suffering from a hacked xcode downloaded from some 3rd party file sharing services (e.g. [this news report](http://www.wired.com/2015/09/hack-brief-malware-sneaks-chinese-ios-app-store/)).
Thanks for the clarification!
i also think the current way of model.py is not effective. it makes maintaining similar things on different bindings harder. it will be great if we can make these codes shared to all languages.

Yes, I think most of the time users won't need to customize the logic in model.py. For optimizers, even if we ignore computational performance issue, it might be better to put common optimizers in C++ backend because the code in each front end will be essentially duplicated. As long as we still leave the interface open so that the users are able to define their own optimizers when needed, this should not be a problem.

I think keep C++ side in minimal way is correct. model.py should rely on language. In this way we can make our library in small size. Eg, if we plan to make mobile version, we only need a minimal core in size of 3-6 MB, instead of 20MB
mobile is another case, we only need to pack the model prediction codes into it. but the short-term question is that we need to write almost identical codes for python/R/julia

Let us being optimistic about this :) There will be common patterns and eventually common patterns goes back to the c++.   It is also about a thin layer of interface. i.e. limited number of simple parameters that can be passed through a C API and how much flexibility to offer. 

In that sense, making a common model interface requires quite a lot of thoughts than expected. For example, how to keep the python callbacks that evaluates the state. How to adapt to multiple in, multiple out case, and how to make these arguments plain C types.  In that sense, the optimizer is a cleaner cut.

As we are also exposing the low level interface, i.e. symbolic execution and ndarray. The model code is more like a battle test case of all the low level modules, which is fun to write :)  It also serves an example on how to deeply customize the code.

It is likely the complicated use-cases will still occur, and we will keep improve the way we think about the model.py   When we have a good idea of where is the clean and effective common pattern that we want to cut, we can definitely bring it down to c++
This is expected behavior, nd.load and nd.save should only take list of arrays. @thirdwing Maybe we can simply not support save a single array
I like the idea of attributes to symbols. This will requires a bit change in the c++ representation of symbol, though, but can make the encoding of name and type a bit more explicit.
Can you give an example of saving a list of objects?

Sorry for my late reply.
I tested cifar-10 in example/cifar10. GPU is much faster than CPU on this data set.
GPU gets the speed of about 460 samples/sec, CPU only 6 samples/sec.
So as @antinucleon said, mlp.py is too tiny to fully use GPU.
Thank you both for helping @mli @antinucleon .
I am glad it works our for you.
we'd better have a detailed doc about the performance

I agree. Providing a reference number (e.g. how many samples/sec on a specific CPU / GPU type, etc.) in the doc or just comments of each example should be very helpful for users to digest whether they are able to run the system properly.
the current solution for multi-input or multi-label is `data_0`, ..., `data_n`, .and `label_0`, ... `label_m`. and ask the user to provide an iterator returning the data in the same order.
I am interested in the part of "more visualization". How is the progress now? What methods are you ready to implement? Maybe I also could contribute some code.

1. The script is not a full script to train an AlexNet, because to train an AlexNet you need to reduce learning rate after several round
2. Please note 81% is top-5 accurate, and `43.8` is top-1 accurate. In my memory, when top-1 accuracy reach 55%, it is almost 81%.
3. What you need to do is stop current training now, load params from current checkpoint, then start train with learning rate of 0.001. After accuracy stops growing, switch to 0.0001

@loveisp Great thanks Dai! I have done nothing yet. You are more than welcome to PR to https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/visualization.py . Currently I think we need some functions to visualize filer, feature map and rnn structure. If you have more great ideas, feel free to PR!

You can [play with symbol](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/notebooks/simple_bind.ipynb) directly, and I will post a LSTM example today or tomorrow to show similar idea. 

eg

```
data = mx.sym.Variable("data")
fc1 = mx.sym.FullyConnected(data=data, xxx)
fc2_1 = mx.sym.FullyConnected(data=fc1, xxx)
fc2_2 = mx.sym.FullyConnected(data=fc1, xxx)
sm1 = mx.sym.Softmax(data=fc2_1, name="sm1")
sm2 = mx.sym.Softmax(data=fc2_2, name="sm2")
```

after bind, you need to set
args["sm1_label"][:] = xx
args["sm2_label"][:] = xxx
